ranked_diseases.explanation: Most common form of Usher syndrome with congenital profound sensorineural hearing loss, typically diagnosed in young adults when retinitis pigmentosa becomes apparent.
Characterized by moderate to severe sensorineural hearing loss from birth, with retinitis pigmentosa developing later in adolescence or young adulthood.
Autosomal recessive disorder with sensorineural hearing loss and thyroid goiter, though goiter may not develop until late childhood or early adulthood.
Autosomal dominant condition with sensorineural hearing loss in 20-25% of cases, often associated with pigmentary abnormalities not mentioned in this case.
Characterized by sensorineural, conductive, or mixed hearing loss, though typically presents with additional features like branchial anomalies and renal malformations.
X-linked disorder with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, though typically associated with progressive kidney disease and ocular abnormalities.
Autosomal dominant progressive sensorineural hearing loss without other systemic features, caused by GJB2 mutations.
Most common form of autosomal recessive nonsyndromic hearing loss, caused by GJB2 mutations, presenting with isolated sensorineural hearing impairment.
